awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1403002

Implantable sensors hold promise to improve quality of life, but their application has been limited due to inadequate accuracy. Sensor arrays (redundant sensors) offer potential to help manage operational problems and provide intrinsic error-checking. This group proposes to apply their experience in developing optical chemical sensors to pursue "multimode" sensors that enable this by combining signal generation tools - two different sensing elements, that use different interactions with the target biochemical to convert concentration into an optical signal. In addition we will develop strategies to have sensors responding to a molecular signal over a wide range of concentrations.  Proposed technologies will make implantable sensors for reliable and will help develop tools for continuous monitoring of patients' health status.

Technical summary: 
Biosensing technology has benefited tremendously from the rapid advancement in nanotechnology, both in new nanocomposite materials as well as exploitation of unique nanoscale phenomena. However, devices for long-term monitoring have not been realized, primarily due to inadequate performance of current implantable chemical sensor technology. The barriers to advancement in this field include (1) Unreliable sensor response that varies with tissue environment and requires frequent calibration; (2) Lack of redundancy and multimodal analyses to provide intrinsic error-checking; and (3) Limited options for quantum advances using current technology. Tiny implants to generate and amplify the small optical signals hold promise for long-term success. However, each approach to convert the concentration of an analyte into an optical signal (the "chemo-optical" transducer element) has drawbacks that challenge its use.  We propose that these limitations may be addressed through a combination of modalities, enabling both improved accuracy as well as error-checking capability. By using micro/nanoscale sensing components, the creation of implants with redundant sensing regions is also possible. Therefore, it is proposed to design sensors to simultaneously produce fluorescence and surface-enhanced Raman (SERS) signals that vary directly and inversely with analyte concentration, respectively. The responses are complementary and provide a means of error-checking. Using glucose as a model analyte, sensors with regions that rely on different transduction schemes (affinity binding vs. enzymatic), yielding different sensitivities, will be developed. All signals may be multiplexed to enable interrogation of the same implant region; spatially discrete regions provide redundancy.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
"Smart" materials that change their optical properties in response to important biochemicals such as sugars, oxygen, acids, etc have shown promise as biosensors for medical, defense, and environmental monitoring. This project aimed to develop advanced versions of materials that have multiple miniscule compartments that respond in different, complementary manners to target molecules. We developed these "multimode" sensors to respond to different interactions with the target biochemical, so they are able to predict concentration in a different way.  They were then combined into a single tiny sliver of material--small enough to inject through a needle. An example of how this may be used is an implantable analyzer for blood composition without having to draw blood.

To prove this material concept was feasible, we first developed individual sets of microscopic particles (capsules) that produce either phosphorescence or Raman signals in response to oxygen and pH, respectively. The microparticles were embedded in soft polymer rods or discs to keep them from moving. We were able to prove that signals from both of the individual components were measurable, sensitive, and reversible. In addition, when an enzyme was added to the same material, we were able to measure the results of the chemical reaction with glucose caused by the enzyme (oxygen consumption, as well as decrease in pH due to acid production).  As expected, the optical signals measured in this process were opposite--phosphorescence increased while Raman scattering decreased with increasing glucose level.

The two components were then combined by mixing the microparticles into the same polymer materials. We were able to image both types of capsules using a specialized microscopy techniques, which showed that the particles were randomly and uniformly distributed throughout the discs.  Finally, we observed that both of the signals were also measurable from these multimode materials and that the embedded microparticle sensors behave the same as they do in the materials with only a single type of encapsulated microparticles.

A key aspect of this work is that the measured phosphorescence and Raman signals vary directly and inversely with biochemical concentration, respectively?therefore, the measurements will be complementary and provide a means of error-checking through redundancy. In addition, we showed that by changing the microcapsule materials slightly, the sensitivity of the responses can be adjusted. Therefore, the materials can be designed to respond over different ranges of interest (normal, low-critical, high-critical, etc). As the two main objectives, this project successfully demonstrated (1) Single- and multi-mode sensing chemistries using both luminescence and SERS; and (2) An efficient and tunable approach to integrate sensing chemistry into a biocompatible polymer matrix with redundant, multimode sensing domains. 

In addition to the above results, which were achieved using oxygen and acidic pH as the observed chemicals and glucose as a model reactant, a number of other sensing systems were developed. Sensors for lactate, basic pH, miRNA, and adenosine were also prototyped.  This project was the main research focus for two PhD dissertations and also supported several other graduate student projects. Overall, the project involved undergraduate and graduate students from chemical, electrical, and biomedical engineering, and neuroscience and included international partnership and exchange programs with researchers in Japan and Korea. The work resulted in roughly 10 scientific papers and 20 presentations and one international patent.


Last Modified: 12/08/2018
Modified by: Michael J Mcshane

    Michael J Mcshane
    Dual Sensor Zoom
  • Illustration of one potential use of polymer materials with embedded particles to respond to biochemicals. An implant residing under skin could report on the concentration of multiple molecules without having to take blood.
    Lindsey Bornhoeft

    Skin Sensor
